content: $SGHC I hope that my ST posts will help teach some serious, novice investor what not to do. The only benefit I personally gain by posting here is a contemporaneous record to help my effort to learn what not to do in public markets. My posting history spans over a time period that includes my mom’s cancer fight, and me taking her to all of her medical appointments—biopsies, scans, surgery, chemo, radiation, and diagnosis of remission. A good portion of my posts were made sitting in the parking lot of Cedars-Sinai Chemotherapy Infusion Area, so I could see my mom through the window, because Covid restrictions didn’t allow anyone to accompany her. I’d be lying if I didn’t admit that going back and reading some of my older posts gives me the sour taste of penny and nickel. But there’s some pure gold there too, so long as it’s read within the context of knowing the author had very little real-world market experience at the time. Just wanted to remind myself of what I’m still doing here. Bullish

$SGHC Maneuver warfare represents—in the words of the United States Marine Corps doctrinal manual, Warfighting—“a state of mind bent on shattering the enemy morally and physically by paralyzing and confounding him, by avoiding his strength, by quickly and aggressively ploiting his vulnerabilities, and by striking him in a way that will hurt him most.” It is the opposite of Attrition warfare. Battles are won by attrition and maneuver: the greater the general, the more he contributes in maneuver; the less he demands in attrition. Bullish

$SGHC Attrition warfare is a military strategy aimed at winning a war by wearing down the enemy to the point of collapse through continuous losses. The word attrition comes from the Latin root atterere, meaning “to rub against,”similar to the “grinding down” of the opponent's forces in attrition warfare. For mid and high ranking officers, it usually involves long stints of indoor confinement at a semi safe location. For lower ranking officers and enlisted men, it usually involves long stints of exposer to harsh elements and continuous enemy contact. “Waiting it out” and “grinding down the enemy” breeds two starkly different experiences for these two groups of soldiers, respectively. Envy and resentment are unavoidable, but are capable of being managed by good leadership.

$SGHC As of today’s closing price, 3.10, based on newly effective share count of 467,983,032, our EV is 1.19B dollars. Less than 1x anticipated 23 revenue. 23 rev growth here is anticipated to be 4%, which is above the current analyst consensus estimate of 23 rev growth for the S&P 500, in aggregate, of 1.9%. And growth in profitability isn’t absent here, as measured by anticipated annual 5% NGR and >16% EBITDA margin growth. Debt-free. 

Yet, the stock price stability here is worse than the Mexican peso, and retail shareholder sentiment has gone from fatalistic to full-blown suicidal. And it finally got to me too. It feels badly fucked. Felt much less scary when the stock dropped in response to lowering guidance and missed numbers. The clear cause and effect provided a comfort blanket. Now it’s just ugly, dark, cold FUD. 

To calculate EV, I converted the 246M euro in unrestricted cash to 263 dollars based on today’s currency conversion rate. 467,983,032 x 3.10 = 1,450 - 263 = 1,187. Bearish

$SGHC If you’ve been doing market-related news reading over the past few days, you’ve gotten to see, in real time, how our banking system relies on trust to function. It’s unreasonable to expect that any bank is liquid enough to satisfy a mass exodus of depositors on a single day. So a bank must not do anything boneheaded, like write loans against overpriced collateral, or over concentrate the total amount of its lending in any one specific sector, industry, or asset profile.  If it does any of those things, it’s only a matter of time before something happens that reveals the bank’s fragility and causes an untenable run on deposits. How many mismanaged regional/speciality banks—powder kegs—are still out there? What will the Fed do to ensure bank—price—stability? Interesting times.
